node.title: Persistent hanging jobs with Stochastic Tools + Griffin, on Sawtooth
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I've recently been using stochastic tools in conjunction with Griffin for providing sensitivity and uncertainty quantification, as well as attempting to develop a surrogate, for a nuclear thermal propulsion project. I've had some success, but I've consistently encountered issues on Sawtooth with simulation initializations, during solves, and at the solve completion. I get hanging jobs frequently, and these are relatively intensive (60 node) jobs. If there is any advice out there, I'd appreciate it. Here are the modules I've been using on sawtooth, loading use.moose and moose-dev:
  1) use.moose                     4) curl/7.61.1-gcc-12.3.0-5t73   7) cmake/3.27.7-gcc-12.3.0-5cfk  10) mpfr/4.2.0-gcc-10.5.0-cec4  13) gcc/12.3.0-gcc-10.5.0-vx2f   16) moose-dev/2023-10-23
  2) flex/2.6.4-gcc-12.3.0-cnsv    5) ncurses/6.1-gcc-12.3.0-7zps   8) patchelf/0.18.0               11) mpc/1.3.1-gcc-10.5.0-mpcb   14) mvapich2/2.3.7-1-gcc-12.3.0
  3) bison/3.0.4-gcc-12.3.0-547w   6) zlib/1.2.13-gcc-12.3.0-c2ww   9) gmp/6.1.2-gcc-10.5.0-wep3     12) zstd/1.4.4-gcc-10.5.0-yue3  15) moose-tools/2023-10-19

Here are a couple examples of the hanging jobs. Thanks in advance if anyone is able to provide some guidance.
Jackson

The last one includes an error in stochastic tools. But still, some ranks were still hanging. Have you seen anything like this @loganharbour , @milljm ?

mvapich2/2.3.7-1-gcc-12.3.0

This does not work with the current timpi algorithm. You need to pass the timpi-sync command line parameters, or avoid mvapich (use openmpi or mpich) when compiling.

Man, I am bad at checking Github. So I switched and compiled Moose + Griffin with mpich on sawtooth, and that has given me stable behavior so far. Now just to wait on Sawtooth to come back up so I can test it more, but I used 80 nodes for a 3 day job and it worked just fine.
I was unsuccessful using openmpi on Lemhi, not sure how/if it functions on Sawtooth.

node.title: Question about BCs in RVE Simulation
node.bodyText:
In the homogenization test input file, small-tests,
there are constraints applied to two additional points ('fix_xy' and 'fix_z') in addition to the fixed point ('fix_all'). I am uncertain whether these two points should be constrained when all constraint_types are strain type. Could someone please clarify why these two extra points are constrained?

Hello
We typically add extra constratins on displacements to avoid homogeneous solutions on displacements. So displacement modes that are also solution of the equations but moving the geometry around. They come from the null space of the equations.
Someone more expert on RVE will have to check whether this is the case here
Guillaume
As of my understanding, fixing one point resolves in restriction of translational modes and the additional two points should be restricted to remove the possibility of the rotation.
There is 6 possible DOFs (3 translations and 3 rotations). Therefore, to restrict all of them, 6 conditions are needed.
So the second point should be very close to the first point?

I dont think that needs to be the case.
You just need to block extraneous rotations and translations, and this can be done a number a ways.
For example with blocking the displacement (with dirichlet BCs) of three points that are not aligned

node.title: Issue inheriting from UserSolutionObject

node.bodyText:
Hello
This is NOT going to work
public Material,
                                   public BaseNameInterface,
                                   public SolutionUserObject

you cant inherit from both a material and a user object, as they are both MooseObject
This is a case where inheritance is the wrong paradigm. You need to use composition. Use a separate class to perform the "Solution" part of the work.
Guillaume
Ah got it, thank you

node.title: Seeking Guidance: Error Encountered when using update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh

node.bodyText:
Conda libraries are supposed to be self-contained in Conda, so seeing something like this is interesting. Feels like external factors at play. What operating system are you using out of curiosity? Also, would you be able to produce the output of the following commands:
conda deactivate
moose/scripts/diagnostics.sh
conda activate moose
moose/scripts/diagnostics.sh
I am asking for a before and after snap shot of the environment variables. Might show us something in the system that is hindering Conda in some odd way.
Thanks!

	conda install moose-dev=

2.  Or adjust your repository to be in sync with moose-dev Conda package.
It seems to be pointed out below that the moose-dev package version required to install the current MOOSE code repository (repository) is inconsistent with the version installed in the current Conda environment. However, I typed conda install moose-dev=2024.04.12 and it showed # All requested packages already installed.

That looks to be a bug in my diagnostic script, although I am not sure how to reproduce it. What the script tried to do was ask our versioner script what version of moose-dev you should have. What it reported back must have been something the diagnostic script couldn't parse.
While this isn't troubleshooting your original issue, I am curious what this reports:
cd moose/scripts
./versioner.py moose-dev --yaml | grep 'install:'
Moving on... Unfortunately nothing jumps out as being off in your environment. I'll need to create myself an Ubuntu 20.04 container and see if I can reproduce this behavior. Judging by the before and after environment, it seems you are running a clean machine. Have you installed anything of note? Other compilers? etc etc?

The output information is as follows:
~/projects-dev/moose/scripts
$ ./versioner.py moose-dev --yaml | grep 'install:'
  install: moose-dev=2024.04.12=build_0

Have you installed anything of note? Other compilers? etc etc?

No, in fact this is a new Ubuntu environment. I reinstalled the system when trying to build the https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/profiling.html environment, and then installed the moose environment according to https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html.
Thanks

The output information is as follows:

Huh. That is precisely what it should return. Meh! Bugs.

No, in fact this is a new Ubuntu environment.

Understood...
I don't think this will have anything to do with it, but by chance have you installed the basics as of yet?
apt install build-essential

Yeah, I have installed it using sudo apt install build-essential. Actually, use sudo apt remove build-essential
I tried to uninstall it, but the same problem still occurred.
Hi @milljm, I would like to ask a question by the way, which Linux version distribution is recommended for the MOOSE environment to run in? When considering installing petsc and libmesh locally.

I don't think what I am posting is going to solve the issue... but
I just realized... you have moose-dev installed yet you are trying to build libMesh. You don't want to do that... installing moose-dev installs everything (including an already built copy of libMesh).
In order to build libMesh using the Conda compilers, a couple things need to happen. We need to uninstall the moose-dev and only install the bits needed up to that point:
conda deactivate
conda activate base
conda env remove -n moose
conda create -n moose moose-petsc moose-libmesh-vtk
conda activate moose
This should get everything leading up to requiring you to supply libMesh on your own.
If IIRC, an additional package is necessary to build libMesh while partially using our Conda packages:
conda install libz
Regardless, I'd like you to try the above, and see if you run into the same error!

which Linux version distribution is recommended for the MOOSE

We don't really have a preference to be honest. However, our build machines running all the continuous integration methods, is runing Rocky 8.8.
There are quite a few users using Ubuntu 20+ so that is definitely supported as well

Hi @milljm, unfortunately, when I tried to use the suggestions you gave, the same problem occurred. I will try to reinstall my ubuntu tomorrow, and then try the installation again using your suggestions.

I wanted to share some good news with you. Today, I managed to reinstall Ubuntu using a virtual machine and successfully installed Moose-PETSc-Libmesh-Wasp. It seems the previous installation issues may have been caused by conflicts between the GCC compilers from conda and apt.
I want to express my gratitude for your support and assistance throughout this process. Your help has been invaluable.
Thank you once again.
Best regards,
Wei

node.title: Grain boundary velocity
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am working on a friction pressure model of grain growth. and referring, I want to know if the velocity (_new_val) in grainboundaryvelosity auxkernel is same as what this paper mentioned in

without eta_top and eta_bottom condition?
Thank you
The paper I am referring to is doi:10.1088/0965-0393/20/6/065008

Also is there any way I can output the value of any variable at every time step. say for example I want to extract the value of _new_value at some quadrature point, is there any post processor or output module for it?

Hello
what is new_value?
a postprocessor? a material property? a variable? a class attribute (of which class?)?
Guillaume

Sorry my bad. In GrainBoundaryVelocity Auxkernel (https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/phase_field/src/auxkernels/GrainBoundaryVelocity.C)
The class
GrainBoundaryVelocity::computeValue()
calculates velocity as _new_val. My question is is the _new_val same as the screenshot?
it seems to be computed different, with 1 / grad_eta as opposed to d n / d eta but it seems to be intent

node.title: Permeability of excavated tunnel - convergence problem
node.bodyText:
Hi PorousFlow experts,
I checked https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/coal_mining.html I noticed that the excavted_perm is set to 0
I find that having a very low perm at the excavated elements make the simulation very difficult to converge.
So here is my setup, I have activate drain BC around the tunnel (below)
  [bc_drain0001_UG]
    type = PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSink
    variable = porepressure_L1
    boundary = 'DRAINSRFUPIT_YXXXX_QXX'
    pt_vals = '0 1e9'
    multipliers = '0 1e9'
    flux_function = 1
    PT_shift = 0.
    fluid_phase = 0
    use_mobility = true    # default is false
  []

on top of that, the flow model is partially saturated with + FLAC relperm m = 2, so this make the perm in the excavated area even lower (which doesn't really help with convergence), I set the sat_lr = 0.25 and it still doesnt really help. in fact I'd like to set alpha to be higher than 1e-6 but the convergence will be much worse.
  [uobj_saturation_optionVG]
    ### ### vanGenuchten (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG.html)
    type = PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG   
    alpha = 1e-06
    m = 0.6
    log_extension = True
    sat_lr = 0.25
  []

    type = PorousFlowRelativePermeabilityFLAC
    phase = 0
    m = 2
    s_res = 0
    sum_s_res = 0

and below is all my Kernels, nothing special, and time_unit is year
  [fluid_mass_dot]
    type = PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative   
    variable = porepressure_L1
    fluid_component = 0
    multiply_by_density = true
  []

   [fluid_flux_fullupwind]
     type = PorousFlowAdvectiveFlux   
     variable = porepressure_L1
     gravity = '0 0 -9.81'            
     fluid_component = 0
   []

However, when I set excav_perm really high, for example 1e3 higher than the model's avg perm, it converges much better but the drainage/phreatic surface is too much/wider than I wanted.
Everything here should be very straightforward, the only uncertain factor for me right now is excavted_perm, should it be higher or extremely low when the removal subdomain for the excavated block isnt an option?
I tagged you guys since you guys are an expert on this topic: @cpgr @WilkAndy
Thank you,
Traiwit

I tried perm_excavated = 0, it actually works BUT only steady-state where PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative isnt there
is there a way to make this works with PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative on?
Do you do anything to the porosity in the excavated area? Is it set to a small value too? It shows up in the time derivative term during the mass balance.

Hi, I set poro_excav is 1, poro_rock is usually around 0.05 and poro_cave is 0.25
 [mat_porosity]
   type = PorousFlowPorosityFromCSV
   read_prop_user_object = uobj_read_poro_fromCsv
   state = prop_state
   state_values = '1 2' #1 is excav 2 is cave
   poro_state_values = '1 0.25'
 []

should this be 0? there is water trapped in that area too (below image is saturation and pwp)

node.title: How to use ExpressionBuilder with DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material> ?

node.bodyText:
Hello
you are getting diamond inheritance errors.
Basically two of the classes DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material> and DerivativeParsedMaterialHelper enable a lot of the same routines, coming from the Material class which is used as a template argument
I get these errors on my machine which a little clearer to interpret
In file included from /Users/giudgl/projects/moose/modules/phase_field/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C:66:
/Users/giudgl/projects/moose/modules/phase_field/src/materials/test.C:40:15: error: non-static member 'declarePropertyDerivative' found in multiple base-class subobjects of type 'DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material>':
    class GmTernaryExtended -> DerivativeMaterialInterface<class Material>
    class GmTernaryExtended -> DerivativeParsedMaterialHelper -> ParsedMaterialHelper<false> -> FunctionMaterialBase<false> -> DerivativeMaterialInterface<class Material>
    _d2GdX1X2(declarePropertyDerivative<Real>("f_name", _X1_name, _X2_name)),
              ^

the solution is likely to simply remove DerivativeParsedMaterialHelper from the parent classes

I removed DerivativeParsedMaterialHelper inheritance.  Now, I get a different kind of error as shown below.
hecking if header needs updating: /home/kamalnath/projects/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h...
Creating Unity /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C...
In file included from /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C:3:
/home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/src/materials/GmTernaryEB.C: In constructor ‘GmTernaryEB::GmTernaryEB(const InputParameters&)’:
/home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/src/materials/GmTernaryEB.C:168:2: error: ‘functionParse’ was not declared in this scope; did you mean ‘FunctionParser’?
  168 |  functionParse(Mobility11);
      |  ^~~~~~~~~~~~~
      |  FunctionParser
make: *** [/home/kamalnath/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:149: /home/kamalnath/projects/panmoose/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.x86_64-pc-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1

You ll need to stick to the routines from DerivativeMaterialInterface<Material>
if you actually require routines from DerivativeParsedMaterialHelper instead, then you should chose to inherit that one instead

node.title: Incorporate TotalFreeEnergy with PolycrystalKernelAction
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I am looking for help where I want to compare the total free energy (as calculated by TotalFreeEnergy auxkernel). But I want to take F taken from PolycrystalKernelAction. If you can give the kernel code snippet that return the total energy in this case will also work. I eventually want to put it in my own kernel.
Thank you

Hello
The  PolycrystalKernelAction only creates the kernels not the material properties.
You can look inside the kernels for how they compute (most likely just retrieve) the total free energy
It creates ACGrGrPoly and ACinterface kernels
